descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Rodney Rogers scored 19 points and Stephon Marbury added 14 as the Phoenix Suns cruised to a 99-71 victory over the Detroit Pistons, who posted their lowest home scoring total in team history.
article.headline: Suns outrebound Pistons 51-32, force 21 turnovers
article.linkText: Suns start second half by holdest Pistons to lowest home total
article.story:
AUBURN HILLS, Mich. (AP) -- As they have done in the past, the Phoenix Suns wanted to show some pride by coming out of the All-Star break playing well. Apparently, the Detroit Pistons didn't. Rodney Rogers scored 19 points and Stephon Marbury added 14 as the Suns routed the Pistons 99-71 Tuesday night. "There are only a couple teams in the league who have been better that us after the All-Star break in the past couple years," Phoenix coach Scott Skiles said. "We know we have to do that again this year. This was a great way to start it." Phoenix, which won for the third time in four games, had a 51-32 rebounding edge and forced 21 turnovers. Penny Hardaway added 10 points, eight rebounds and five assists. "We felt really good coming out of the break and we wanted to come out and take it to them," Hardaway said. "We played a complete game tonight, and that's what we have to do. No one is giving us a chance, so we have to prove them wrong. It would be a wasted season if we (kept) playing the way we did in the first half." Jerry Stackhouse and Corliss Williamson led Detroit with 10 points each. The Pistons set a franchise record for fewest points in a home game. "I thought we were going to play very well tonight, but I was wrong," said Pistons coach Rick Carlisle. "We got beat every way possible. There's not more else I can say." Detroit went into the All-Star break having won three straight and 10 of 13, but the momentum didn't survive the time off. The Pistons managed just 31 points in the first half, shooting 33 percent from the floor and turning the ball over 11 times. "When you don't put the ball in the basket, things like that are going to happen," Stackhouse said. "We didn't play hard, and we didn't deserve to win. Even if we had won, we wouldn't have deserved it." Phoenix shot only 40 percent but used 12 offensive rebounds to build a 46-31 halftime lead. The Suns then had a 12-3 run early in the third, increasing their lead to 60-36. "We've had some games where we've blown big leads, and we didn't want to do that again," Hardaway said. "We slack off defensively and let teams get up the floor and into their offense. Tonight, we were up and on them and took the game away from them at the beginning of the second half." The Pistons didn't score their 50th point until the last minute of the third quarter, and trailed 74-52 at period's end. The loss was even tougher for Pistons center Cliff Robinson, who was traded from Phoenix to Detroit in the off-season. "I didn't sit at home last night and say that my whole season depended on winning this game, but it would have been nice to beat them," he said. "I think there were a few times in the game when I tried to do too much and turned the ball over."

Game notes
The Pistons made two roster moves -- activating rookies Ratko Varda and Rodney White and placing Brian Cardinal (knee) and Victor Alexander (back) on the injured list. Varda made his NBA debut in the fourth quarter, scoring five points. ... Phoenix beat the Pistons by 33, 106-73, in their previous visit to the Palace. Cliff Robinson had 27 for the Suns in that game. He had four points and seven turnovers for Detroit on Tuesday. ... Scott Skiles is 21-8 in February since taking over as Phoenix's coach. ... Alton Ford was the only player on either roster who did not score.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
